info.game_comments:
1987 Senior Tournament quarterfinal game 1.
Inaugural Senior Tournament game.

(1, 1).clue: It's said these furry rodents were named for the Chincha Indians, who used to eat them

(2, 1).clue: He had affairs with Cassius' wife & Brutus' mother, giving the guys good reason to stab him

(3, 1).clue: First made in the 17th century, this country's Imari ware includes blue & white sake bottles

(4, 1).clue: You don't hit someone with this "lead pipe"; you eat it with meatballs

(5, 1).clue: The Digambara monks of India believe that salvation is not possible for this sex

(6, 1).clue: The hollow cone through which cheerleaders scream at you

(1, 2).clue: Because of man, the zebra-like quagga & stellar's sea cow are both this

(2, 2).clue: What the Roman elite did with dormice, ostrich wings & flamingo tongues

(3, 2).clue: The controversial china Nancy Reagan ordered is bordered in this, her favorite color

(5, 2).clue: The Phoenicians used to sacrifice these to the god Moloch, definitely not according to Spock

(6, 2).clue: Dancers' rhythm instruments whose name derives from Spanish word for chestnut, "castana"

(1, 3).clue: Most mammals are homoiothermic, which means this is constant year-round

(2, 3).clue: Roman historians usually wrote in this language until Cato the Elder wrote "Origines" in Latin

(3, 3).clue: "Queen's ware" was named for the wife of this last king of the American colonies

(4, 3).clue: To order liver cooked with these, a waitress yells, "Put out the lights & cry!"

(5, 3).clue: In 1934, at the age of 79, Evangeline Booth became the 1st woman general in this religious "corps"

(1, 4).clue: Monotremes are the only mammals which give birth this way

(2, 4).clue: Among these, a sector was a light-armored version of the heavily armored Samnite

(3, 4).clue: Firm famed for its pale blue jasperware adorned with while classical figures

(4, 4).clue: If you want this Irish immigrant entree, scream "red horse, put a wreath on it!"

(5, 4).clue: In a traditional Jewish wedding, the couple is married under 1 of these, symbolic of the bridal chamber

(1, 5).clue: All mammals of the order pinnipedia have this kind of feet

(2, 5).clue: On the earliest known Roman calendar, these were the 7th, 8th, 9th & 10th months

(3, 5).clue: The 1st European soft-paste porcelain was made by a member of this famous family of Florence

(4, 5).clue: If you "brand bossy", you're doing this

(5, 5).clue: Name of this religion founded in the 7th c. can be translated as "submission", "surrender" or "commitment"

(1, 1).clue: This country now has the largest submarine fleet in the world

(2, 1).clue: It was established from the fortune left our gov't in 1829 by British scientist James Smithson

(3, 1).clue: A strapless slipper, or the farm animal who's probably too stubborn to wear it

(4, 1).clue: F. Tennyson & C. Tennyson Turner wrote "Poems by 2 Brothers" with this more famous brother

(5, 1).clue: Apple Valley's most famous citizen, he once sponsored a girls' bowling team called the "Triggerettes"

(6, 1).clue: On their knees, baritones sing to her, "You is my woman now"

(1, 2).clue: Elizabeth I knighted him upon his Golden Hind

(2, 2).clue: By a rules committee decision, this has been served in the Senate restaurant every day since 1907

(3, 2).clue: Southern slang for a peanut, or southern name for a Pyle on "The Andy Griffith Show"

(4, 2).clue: Tho not usually regarded as black authors, this former French pere & fils were of black heritage

(5, 2).clue: Abbreviate his native state & you'll find his 1st name; watch "Three's Company" & you'll find his  son

(6, 2).clue: As George M. Cohan said "It's a grand old name"

(1, 3).clue: Docked in New England it's called the oldest commissioned ship afloat in any of the world's navies

(2, 3).clue: Tho much larger, this was built in the exact proportions of Ancient Egyptian obelisks

(3, 3).clue: (AUDIO DAILY DOUBLE)A Northerner who goes South for the winter, or this 1970 hit: "When I was young my heart was young then too..."

(4, 3).clue: Tho his novel "The Rainbow" was banned as "obscene", he wrote a sequel, "Women in Love", anyway

(6, 3).clue: If your name is this, & you're Irish, "I'll take you home again"

(1, 4).clue: Among former names of this service was "The Revenue Marines"

(2, 4).clue: Washington is divided into 4 unequal quadrants with this building at its center

(3, 4).clue: The Archbishop of Manila, or what you shouldn't commit in front of him

(6, 4).clue: Of her, it's asked "When did your sparkle turn to fire & your warmth become desire?"

(2, 5).clue: Tho work on it began in 1907, this famed Episcopal church has never been completed
(2, 5).correct response: Washington Cathedral (Church of St. Peter or National Cathedral)

(3, 5).clue: A proverbial saying, or the brand of coffee you drink while thinking of it

(4, 5).clue: Religious mania forced this Russian to burn his sequel to his great novel "Dead Souls"

(6, 5).clue: "At night, dear heart, for you I pine," usually in groups of 4

(0, 0).clue: It was Steve Allen who coined this show's question, "Is it bigger than a breadbox?"
